EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


On June 20, 1996, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) issued the Risk Management Program Rule.  This rule is aimed at preventing accidental releases and reducing the severity of those releases that do occur.  This Rule has been amended and updated on several occasions.

Wastewater treatment facilities with on-site storage of a A?processA? which contains any of the extremely hazardous toxic and flammable substances listed in the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) at 40 CFR 68.130 in an amount above the A?threshold quantityA? specified for that substance, is required to develop and implement a risk management program.  For the City of Inman wastewater treatment plant, liquid chlorine used for the disinfection process exceeds EPSA?s threshold quantity and sulfur dioxide, also used in the disinfection process, exceeds the OSHA threshold quantity.  For the City of Inman wastewater treatment plant, the facility must be in compliance no later than the date on which there is more than a threshold quantity of a listed substance on the site.

Depending on the specific characteristics of a covered process, the POTW may be subject to one of three different sets of requirements (called program levels).  The Inman facility falls into Program 3, the highest level.]

The Risk Management Program has four major components:
A?    Hazard Assessment,
A?    Prevention Program
A?    Emergency Response Plan, and a
A?    Risk Management Plan.

Each of these components is address in subsequent sections of the Risk Management Plan (RMP).

The RMP rule requires that a Management System be in place to:
A?    Develop a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program elements;
A?    Designate a qualified person or position with the overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements; and
A?    Document the names of people or positions and define the lines of authority through an organizational

chart or other similar document, if responsibility is assigned for implementing individual requirements of the risk management program to people or positions other than the person or position with overall responsibility for the risk management program. 

Management commitment to process safety is a critical element of any facilityA?s risk management program.  Since the program requires ongoing implementation of accident prevention and emergency response measures, management commitment does not end when the risk management plan is submitted to EPA.

In the hazard assessment section of the Risk Management Program, facilities must evaluate the possible consequences of an accidental release to nearby communities, schools, hospitals, recreational facilities, and other public and environmentally sensitive areas by predicting the "worst-case" and "alternative" (i.e., more likely) release scenarios.  Facilities must also document past accidents that have occurred at the facility for the last five years.

There are two areas to be addressed as a party of the Hazard Assessment component of the Risk Management Program as follows:
A?    Five Year Accident History 
A?    Offsite Consequence Analysis

The City of Inman facility has had no reportable releases in the past five years.

The worst-case release scenarios for chlorine and sulfur dioxide from the City of Inman wastewater treatment plant were evaluated.  The toxic endpoints are: 
Chlorine: 0.0087 mg/L (3 ppm)
Sulfur Dioxide: 0.0078 mg/L (3 ppm)

The regulations require that tables or models for atmospheric dispersion analysis be used that appropriately account for gas density.  For the specific case of WWTPs, chlorine and sulfur dioxide are always dense gases (that is, denser than air).

Chlorine is present in one-ton cylinders at the facility.  The worst-case scenario assumes that this quantity, i.e., 2,000 pounds, is completely released over a period of 10 minutes (e.g., 200-lb/min rate of release).  The predicted distance to

the toxic endpoint for this scenario based on modeling information is 3.0 miles.  This distance is based on the following assumptions:

Release Location    Outdoors (Worst Case)
Quantity    200 Pounds/Min.
Release Height    Ground Level
Wind Speed    1.5 Meters/Sec.
Atmospheric Stability    Class F
Temperature    EPA Model
Humidity     EPA Model
Topography    Rural
Density    Dense

The worst-case scenario assumes that this quantity, i.e., 150 pounds, is completely released over a period of 10 minutes (e.g., 15-lb/min rate of release).  The predicted distance to the toxic endpoint for this scenario based on modeling information 0.7 miles.  This distance is based on the following assumptions:

The rule requires that the RMP include an estimate of the residential populations within the geographical areas that could be affected by the hypothetical worst-case or alternative releases which have been analyzed.  In addition, the RMP must indicate whether certain types of public receptors and environmental receptors are within the circles.

Based on information from the 2000 census tracts in the vicinity of the City of Inman wastewater treatment plant, an estimated population of 12,952 people is currently within the 3.0 mile radius to the endpoint for the worst case release scenario.  There are also several industrial plants, and commercial areas.  There are no schools, hospitals, prisons, public recreational areas or arenas within the circle for the City of Inman wastewater treatment plant.  There are also several industrial plants, and commercial areas.  There are no schools, hospitals, prisons, public recreational areas or arenas within the circle for the City of Inman wastewater treatment plant.

There are no environmental receptors areas such as national or state parks, forests, or monuments; officially designated wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, refuges, or areas; and Federal wilderness areas within the circle for the City of Inman wastewater treatment plant.

The EPA Prevention Program includes the requirements of the OSHA PSM standard.  Whenever possible, EPA used OSHA's language verbatim.  However, there were a few terms that EPA had to change to reflect the differences between its authority and OSHA's.  The PHA should also be updated or revalidated whenever there is a new hazard or risk created by changes to the process.  

Part 68 requires implementation of an emergency response program if facility employees will respond to some releases involving regulated substances.  An emergency response program consists of an emergency response plan, emergency response equipment procedures, employee training, and procedu

res to ensure the program is up-to-date.

EPA recognizes that, in some cases, it may not be appropriate for employees to conduct response operations for releases of regulated substances.  EPA does not intend to force such facilities to develop emergency response capabilities.  At the same time, facility managers are responsible for ensuring effective emergency response to any releases at the facility.  In the case of the City of Inman wastewater treatment plant, public responders other than plant personnel are available and are capable of providing adequate response.

EPA has adopted a policy for non-responding facilities which allows certain facilities to develop an emergency action plan to ensure employee safety, rather than a full-fledged emergency response plan.  Since there is likely to be toxic regulated substances above the threshold quantity present at the City of Inman Wastewater Treatment plant, an emergency coordinator has been designated to work with the local emergency planning and response officials on chemical emergency preparedness issues.

Once the RMP has been prepared and submitted, EPA will make it available to the public. Members of the public may obtain copies of RMPs by requesting them from EPA in writing.  In view of the publicA?s access to RMPs, it should be expected that the community will discuss the hazards and risks associated with the facility as indicated in the RMP. 
Communication with the public can be an opportunity to develop a relationship with the community and build a level of trust among neighbors, and the community at large.  By complying with the RMP rule, a number of steps are being taken to prevent accidents and protect the community.  These steps are the individual elements of the risk management program.  A well-designed and properly implemented risk management program will set the stage for informative and productive dialogue with the community.
